title: The Illegal Execution of James.
description:
The illegal execution of James
A political scandal that accidentally confirmed history.

This passage is often cited by historians as the most authentic reference to Jesus outside the Bible precisely because it is so casual. Josephus wasn't trying to spread the Gospel; he was simply reporting on why a High Priest got fired. By using "Jesus, who was called Christ" merely as a label to distinguish which James was on trial, Josephus inadvertently confirms that Jesus was a known public figure in 62 AD, even among the Roman and Jewish elite who opposed Him.
Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ShFrtcV_tm8&t=2124s

description:
Josephus Knew Jesusâ€™ Executioners
Josephus wasn't just a historian; he was practically sitting at the prosecution's table.

Today, we map out the terrifyingly small world of 1st Century Jerusalem. This is awesome; we are proving that Josephus was professionally subservient to the specific family dynasty dedicated to wiping out the early Church.

If Josephus was taking orders from the man who killed James, and whose father killed Jesus, it completely reframes the Testimonium Flavianum (Josephusâ€™s famous passage about Jesus). 
It suggests that Josephus didn't learn about Jesus from public records or street rumors. He likely heard about Him over dinner with the very men who signed the death warrants. It makes Josephusâ€™s writings less of a "history lesson" and more of an "insider leak" from the enemies of the Gospel.

title: Luke has a tendency to abbreviate, Matthew has a tendency to simplify. We see this on several
description:
I donâ€™t consider these differences to be contradictions (when I find differences in their gospels). On the surface, they might look that way, but when we look deeper, the meaning remains consistent.

Many of these differences, though not all, likely come from the way ancient authors were trained to write. In the first century, students learned to summarize, paraphrase, and rearrange material according to certain literary techniques. These methods were common in ancient biography and history. So itâ€™s reasonable to expect that the Gospel writers, following those same conventions, used similar approaches in their accounts.

title: When a Skeptical Historian Strengthens the Case.
description:
We usually look for "friendly" witnesses to prove historical facts. But this conversation reveals why the most valuable testimony often comes from the opposition.

If Josephus was rubbing shoulders with Caiaphas and the High Priests, the very people who wanted to erase this movement, and still recorded these details, itâ€™s not just history anymore. Itâ€™s a "hostile witness" corroborating the story against their own interest. That is the gold standard of evidence in any court of law, ancient or modern.

In this video, we break down how a simple social network analysis shifts Josephus from a distant historian to a guy who was practically in the room where the decisions were made.

title: These appearancesâ€”to individuals and groups, to friends and foes alikeâ€”are best explained...
description:
Letâ€™s see how the resurrection hypothesis holds up.
In terms of explanatory scope and power, it couldnâ€™t be better.

Now, what about the question of being ad hoc? As far as I can tell, there are no assumptions made without evidence. Some might argue that it presupposes Godâ€™s existence, since if Jesus rose, it would almost certainly be a supernatural event. But thatâ€™s not a baseless assumption; thereâ€™s good evidence for Godâ€™s existence.

As for plausibility, we can treat it as neutralâ€”it neither passes nor fails that test.

So, in conclusion, the standard historical method for assessing hypotheses strongly suggests that Jesus rose from the dead.

title: We've got an early testimony from first Clement that Peter and Paul were martyred.

He uses language suggesting that they â€œsuffered unto death,â€ which implies that they faced persecution to the point of dying. While the phrasing isnâ€™t completely explicit, the context strongly suggests that Clement viewed Peter and Paul as martyrs for their faith.

title: Me explaining that Jesusâ€™ resurrection is the best explanation for the empty tomb.
description:
Even the earliest critics of Christianity didnâ€™t deny the empty tomb, they just tried to explain it away.
Matthew mentions the claim that the disciples stole the body. By A.D. 150, Justin Martyr says that rumor was still being spread. Tertullian later reports another version: the gardener supposedly moved the body so no one would trample his lettuce patch. And Celsus, in the late second century, claimed the disciples merely dreamed the resurrectionâ€”â€œand besides,â€ he said, â€œthey were just hysterical women.â€

In other words, nobody in those early centuries was saying the tomb wasnâ€™t empty. The debate wasnâ€™t over whether it was empty, but why.

title: My bro and I after telling some Christians that they might be placing more weight on biblical...
description:
As Michael Bird, an evangelical New Testament scholar, has pointed out: many preach the inerrancy of the Bible but practice the inerrancy of their interpretations.
For me, inerrancy means that the Bible is inerrant in what it teachesâ€”in its message. Even Norman Geisler, who was about as conservative on inerrancy as one can get and helped shape the Chicago Statement, admitted in his Big Book of Bible Difficulties that there are errors in our present text. The Chicago Statement itself acknowledges that inerrancy applies only to the autographs, not to the copies we have today.
So letâ€™s be honest: our current Bibles do contain errors. Could God have preserved a perfectly inerrant text? Of course. But He didnâ€™t. This informs me He didnâ€™t consider it necessary for us to have one.
.

title: Me after telling them Jesus didnâ€™t mean three literal days in the tomb.
description:
If we take the three-day motif literally, then there's a contradiction.

In Estherâ€™s story, she commands the people to fast for three days, but then goes to the king on the third day, not after three full days.

So what gives?

This is a clue that "three days" in ancient literature was often a flexible, idiomatic expression, not a stopwatch countdown. We see this pattern in Jewish, Christian, and even Akkadian writings.

That matters when interpreting the Gospels. The timing of Jesus' resurrection isn't a contradiction, it fits within the common, non-literal use of â€œthree daysâ€ at the time.

Historical context doesnâ€™t weaken Scripture, it helps us understand it more accurately.

title: People saying the Bible is full of contradictions when they donâ€™t know what a compositional...
description:
Recognizing that the Gospel authors used compositional devices helps us understand why differences exist among their accounts. It keeps us from forcing artificial harmonizations and offers more credible explanations than assuming errors.

Scholars like J. L. Moles and M. Pelling note that techniques such as compression, displacement, conflation, and transferal were common across ancient writings. If thatâ€™s true, we should expect to find them in the Gospelsâ€”and we do.

So when skeptics claim the Gospels contradict each other, the issue isnâ€™t contradiction but composition. These writers worked within the conventions of first-century biography, not modern ones. Once we read them through that historical lens, the differences make senseâ€”and the Gospels come into sharper focus.

title: When my pastor realizes how much I can defend the Christian faith withÂ apologetics.
description:
Tips for Becoming a Better Apologist

1. Read widely
Start by immersing yourself in apologetics literature. There are plenty of excellent books available. Be a voracious reader. The more perspectives you engage with, the stronger your understanding will become.

2. Watch debates
Observe how leading Christian apologists and scholars present their arguments and how their opponents respond. Seasoned debaters have encountered a wide range of objections and have refined their reasoning through experience. Watching these exchanges will help you recognize which arguments hold up under critical scrutiny and why.

3. Practice through roleplay
As you learn new arguments, practice them in discussion settings. Roleplay conversations with others, especially those who can offer honest, critical feedback. This helps you fine-tune your reasoning and communicate more effectively.

By doing these things, youâ€™ll not only grow in knowledge but also develop the confidence and skill to engage thoughtfully and persuasively in defense of the Christian faith.

title: In 1 Corinthians 15, Paul doesnâ€™t just present the resurrection as proof of eternal life.
description:
As my friend, Gary Habermas explained, at the very end of the chapter, Paul urges believers to give themselves fully to the work of the Lord, because their labor is not in vain. Thenâ€”without a chapter break in the original letterâ€”he immediately moves into chapter 16, telling the Corinthians to set aside an offering for the poor saints.

The logic is powerful: If Christ is raised, then Christianity is true. If Christianity is true, it should shape how you liveâ€”your generosity, your priorities, even your finances.

So in just a few verses, Paul ties the resurrection not only to our eternal hope but also to our ethical responsibility: live faithfully, work diligently, and care for those in need.

title: Is it Time to Rethink Biblical Inerrancy? A Much-Needed Debate.
description:
Is there room in the church for a "flexible inerrancy," in which the Gospel writers adapted and invented sayings of Jesus according to their theological interests?
 For example, is it within the bounds of inerrancy to conclude that Jesus never said the words, "I thirst," although that sentiment captures his goals? 
These questions are at the root of a big debate within the evangelical church. And today, we have Dr. Michael Licona and Dr. John West to discuss these issues and more. 
Without insulting one side or the other, please let us know what you think about the ISSUES and why.
-With @SeanMcDowell and @discoveryinstitute

title: What am I actually observing when I read the Gospels? ...Letâ€™s look at some specifics.
description:
Some readers may feel uncomfortable at first, but you have to ask: What am I actually observing when I read the Gospels? Take an example: Mark says the disciples were debating among themselves about who was the greatest, and Jesus asked them what they were discussing. Matthew, on the other hand, says they asked Jesus directly, â€œWho is the greatest?â€

When you face surface discrepancies like that, what do you do? Do you say they were two different occasions or try another explanation? Would that really satisfy you? And if a Mormon, Jehovahâ€™s Witness, or Muslim gave you the same kind of answer about their book, would you be satisfied then?

The point isnâ€™t that God is being exposed or that Scripture is somehow embarrassed. Whatâ€™s really being challenged is our own view of Scriptureâ€”how we read the Gospels accurately and as they were intended.

title: Was the Tomb of Jesus Truly Empty?
description:
What about the empty tombâ€”how solid is the evidence? Many apologists include it as a key fact for the resurrection, and a majority of critical scholars (especially Christian ones) affirm it. Yet, far fewer non-Christian scholars grant the empty tomb, making it a point of caution.

Still, even skeptical scholars like Bart Ehrman acknowledge that the disciples sincerely believed Jesus rose bodily from the dead. Others, like Dale Allison, carefully affirm the empty tomb while striving to avoid bias. The question becomes whether weâ€™re too quick to accept it because of our own hopesâ€”or whether the evidence stands on its own merit.

Regardless, the historical record is clear: the earliest disciples truly believed in a physical, bodily resurrection. That conviction, whether or not one includes the empty tomb as a fact, demands explanation.
#Jesus #Baptists #Calvinists #Pentecostals #Christians

title: Can Some of the Toughest Gospel Contradictions Be Solved?
description:
Are these real contradictionsâ€”or compressed narratives with different emphases? Matthew includes the flight to Egypt to highlight prophecy fulfillment (â€œout of Egypt I called my sonâ€), while Luke omits that episode, moving from Bethlehem to the temple dedication and then to Nazarethâ€”likely compressing the timeline. Historians often omit details not central to their aims.

The famous Judas case raises similar questions. Matthew says Judas hanged himself; Acts says he fell headlong and burst open. Rather than forcing a single physical sequence, consider Lukeâ€™s tendency to skip steps: Acts may be describing Judasâ€™s body at burialâ€”bloated and decomposingâ€”rolling into the valley (Gehenna) and rupturing. In that reading, both accounts can be true, each selecting different moments. These difficult differences donâ€™t undermine the core claim: if Jesus rose, Christianity is true; the minor divergences donâ€™t change that.
____________________

title: Why Johnâ€™s Gospel Reads Differently â€” And Why Thatâ€™s Not â€œJesus Seminar Lightâ€.
description:
In this clip I respond  to the claim that my views on Johnâ€™s Gospel echo the controversial Jesus Seminar. I explains how ancient biographers used compositional devices, why Johnâ€™s Gospel is considered a â€œspiritualâ€ account, and how evangelical scholars like Craig Blomberg, D.A. Carson, F.F. Bruce, and others recognize Johannine adaptation without compromising biblical truth.

title: Why the Resurrection Changes Everything | Dr. Gary Habermas & Dr. Mike Licona.
description:
When I called Gary back in 1989 with tough questions about the Bible, he gave me the answer that changed everything: Did Jesus rise from the dead? If the resurrection is true, then Christianity is true â€” even when we wrestle with other questions. That truth has shaped my faith ever since.

In this conversation, Gary Habermas and I talk about how studying the resurrection not only strengthens our confidence in the gospel but also gives us hope in grief, courage in suffering, and practical guidance for everyday life. From dealing with doubts to facing the death of loved ones, the resurrection changes everything.

If youâ€™ve ever struggled with doubts, grief, or fear of the future, I believe this conversation will encourage you and remind you of the hope we have in Jesus.

title: Some people may be placing more weight on biblical inerrancy than God Himself doesâ€”and thatâ€™s not...
description:
As Michael Bird, an evangelical New Testament scholar, has pointed out: many preach the inerrancy of the Bible but practice the inerrancy of their interpretations.

For me, inerrancy means that the Bible is inerrant in what it teachesâ€”in its message. Even Norman Geisler, who was about as conservative on inerrancy as one can get and helped shape the Chicago Statement, admitted in his Big Book of Bible Difficulties that there are errors in our present text. The Chicago Statement itself acknowledges that inerrancy applies only to the autographs, not to the copies we have today.

So letâ€™s be honest: our current Bibles do contain errors. Could God have preserved a perfectly inerrant text? Of course. But He didnâ€™t. This informs me He didnâ€™t consider it necessary for us to have one.
____________________

title: Why the Gospels Look Different...
description:
Some claim the Gospels contradict each otherâ€”but is that really the case? Ancient writers often used compositional devices that adjusted details to fit the style of biography at the time. 
Classicists recognize this, and when we apply it to the Gospels, it helps explain the differences we see. These variations arenâ€™t errors or sloppy historyâ€”theyâ€™re part of how ancient biographies were written.

title: When my critics wonder why people arenâ€™t confronting meâ€”why my friends havenâ€™tâ€”I can tell you...

That was a tough time, and I wanted to change my mindâ€”it wouldâ€™ve my life easier at the timeâ€”but I stayed true to my research. Even if Iâ€™m wrong, I remain convinced of my position.

So, noâ€”silence isnâ€™t always fear. Many agree, some are unsure, but among my friends who are colleagues in apologetics and New Testament scholarship, thereâ€™s no alarm over the ideas I shared.

title: I believe what some are doing is assuming that because the Gospels are ancient biographies of...
description:
Even J. I. Packer, one of the main scholars who crafted the Chicago Statement on Biblical Inerrancy, has said that the first chapters of Genesis are a quasi-liturgical celebration of the fact of creationâ€”not at all what we would have seen had we been hovering above the chaos of it all. He asks, â€œWere there two treesâ€”the Tree of Life and the Tree of the Knowledge of Good and Evilâ€”in the Garden of Eden? I donâ€™t know. Trees were symbols in poetry back then.â€ He continues, â€œWas there really a serpent in the garden? I donâ€™t know. But the message being communicated there and in that genre is true.â€

So, when I come to the Gospels, I ask: Do you want to interpret a parableâ€”like the parable of the Prodigal Son or the Good Samaritanâ€”as if everything about it were recalling historical events? If so, youâ€™re making a bad move with genre.
____________________

title: ğŸ“– â€œMark Never Said Jesus Was Divineâ€â€¦ Are You Sure About That?
description:
Some critics claim the idea that Jesus is God was a later inventionâ€”
That Mark, the earliest Gospel, didnâ€™t teach Jesusâ€™ divinity.

But letâ€™s walk through Mark real quickâ€¦ ğŸ‘‡

ğŸ”¹ Mark 1 â€“ John the Baptist prepares the way for Jesus.
(Mark is applying Isaiah 40 which prepares the way for God.)
ğŸ”¹ Mark 2 â€“ Jesus forgives sinsâ€”and the religious leaders say, â€œOnly God can do that.â€
ğŸ”¹ Mark 3 â€“ Jesus casts out demons and says He has bound the strong man (Satan) to plunder his house.
ğŸ‘‰ What human binds Satan?
ğŸ”¹ Mark 4 â€“ Jesus calms the storm. The Old Testament says only God can do that.
ğŸ”¹ Mark 5 â€“ Jesus raises the dead. Again, a divine act.
ğŸ”¹ Mark 6 â€“ Jesus walks on water. The Old Testament says only God treads on the waves.
ğŸ”¹ Mark 9 â€“ Jesus casts out a demon without praying, then tells His disciples, â€œThis kind only comes out by prayer.â€
Theyâ€™re stunned. Why? He didnâ€™t pray.
ğŸ‘‰ Implication: He doesnâ€™t need to.
ğŸ”¹ Mark 12 â€“ Jesus calls Himself Davidâ€™s Lord, not just Davidâ€™s son.
(Who is greater than King David?)
ğŸ”¹ Mark 13â€“14 â€“ Jesus speaks of returning as the Son of Man in glory and judgmentâ€”sharing God's authority.

From chapter one to the end, Mark shows us a Jesus who speaks, acts, and is worshiped like God.
The apostles didnâ€™t â€œevolveâ€ their view of Jesus.
They knew who He was from the beginning.

title: When we read any kind of literature, understanding the genre matters.You donâ€™t read poetry...
description:
âœï¸ The Gospels are ancient biographies.
How do we know?

-They focus on a single main character (Jesus), not an event or era.
-They begin with ancestry (think: Matthew, Luke, even John!)
-They largely skip the childhood and jump straight into Jesusâ€™ public lifeâ€”just like other ancient biographies.
-They're about 10â€“20k words long (the perfect scroll length).

And most importantly, they aim to reveal character through words and actionsâ€”just like Plutarch did with figures like Alexander the Great.

ğŸ“š Understanding genre helps us read betterâ€”
And it helps us take the Gospels more seriously, not less.

title: Jesus didnâ€™t stop being Godâ€”He chose not to cling to His divine privileges. Instead, He willingly...
description:
In Philippians 2, Paul writes that Jesus â€œexisted in the form of Godâ€ but â€œemptied Himselfâ€ and took on â€œthe form of a servant.â€ At first glance, that might sound like Jesus gave up His divinityâ€”but thatâ€™s not what Paul is saying.

Instead, Paul is contrasting two â€œformsâ€ or roles:

Form of God = Jesusâ€™ role in divine glory, authority, and status

Form of a servant = Jesusâ€™ role in humility, service, and suffering as a human

Paul goes on to say that Jesus was â€œmade in human likenessâ€ and â€œfound in appearance as a man.â€ This shows a distinction between what Jesus is by nature (divine) and how He chose to act (as a servant).

This is key:
Nature = who He is
Role = how He functioned

Just like a king can take off his crown and serve the poor without ceasing to be royalty,
Jesus laid aside His heavenly status to serveâ€”but He remained divine.

.
.

.
.

title: If the traditional view of inerrancyâ€”and the view of inspiration that leads to itâ€”were...
description:
Markâ€™s Gospel uses rough Greek on occasionâ€”like the word ekballÅ (to drive out) for how the Spirit sent Jesus into the wilderness. But when Matthew and Luke retell the same event, they soften the language. Why? Theyâ€™re editing for style.

Luke also seems to confuse details in the parable of the minasâ€”mixing elements from Matthewâ€™s version of the talents. Scholars call this editorial fatigue. And then thereâ€™s Paul, who literally says, â€œI donâ€™t remember if I baptized anyone elseâ€ (1 Cor. 1:16).

If every word was dictated by God, would we expect memory lapses and stylistic cleanups? Or do these examples suggest something else is going on?

Thatâ€™s why building a bottom-up view of Scripture mattersâ€”one that considers not only what Scripture says, but how it actually looks.

title: 2 Corinthians 13:3 is a fascinating verse. Itâ€™s rarely mentioned in discussions about...
description:
In that passage, Paul says, â€œYou want proof that Christ is speaking through me?â€ That sure sounds like inspiration, doesnâ€™t it? Maybe even something close to dictation, similar to how prophets spoke in the Old Testament.

But here's the tension: if Christ is speaking through Paul, and yet Paul can still have a memory lapse while writing Scripture (like in 1 Corinthians 1:16), then ask yourselfâ€”could he also have had a memory lapse while preaching?

Think about it: across three decades of preaching, is it possible Paul ever misattributed a teachingâ€”like quoting something from Jeremiah and accidentally saying it was from Isaiah? Could a mistake like that happen, even while Christ was speaking through him?

If itâ€™s possible in his preaching, why not in his writing?

Thatâ€™s something worth pondering. You donâ€™t need to come to a hard conclusion, but ask honestly: Could a biblical writer make a minor error in detail, even while being inspired by God?

So what do we do with inerrancy?

Maybe the traditional syllogism needs refining:

God cannot err.

The Bible is the Word of God . . . in its meaning and message.

Therefore, the Bible cannot errâ€¦ in its meaning and message.

That version aligns more closely with what we actually observe in Scriptureâ€”and still affirms its divine authority.

title: Our concept of inspiration shapes our understanding of the doctrine of inerrancy
description:
What often happens in discussions about inerrancy is this: our concept of inspiration ends up shaping our understanding of the doctrine of inerrancy.

If you believe that God dictatedâ€”or nearly dictatedâ€”every word of Scripture, then naturally, youâ€™re likely to hold to a strict view of inerrancy.

But if you see more of a human element in the formation of Scripture, that view doesnâ€™t necessarily demand inerrancy in the most rigid, technical sense.

ğŸ‘‰ How we understand inspiration impacts how we define inerrancy.

title: People start with a few verses or preconceived ideas about what Scripture must be, and then...
description:
What we often seeâ€”just like New Testament scholar Mark Strauss (an evangelical and member of the Evangelical Theological Society) points outâ€”is a top-down approach to Scripture.

But Strauss argues for a bottom-up approach instead:
Look at what we actually observe in Scriptureâ€”the patterns, the voices, the differencesâ€”and also consider what Scripture says about itself.

By combining both observation and self-claims, we arrive at a more grounded and faithful view of what Scripture truly is.

And that's exactly what Iâ€™m proposing here: a bottom-up approach to understanding the Bible.

title: God-breathed doesnâ€™t mean dictated. Theopneustos points to origin, not process.
description:
So, what does theopneustosâ€”God-breathedâ€”actually mean? 
The truth is, weâ€™re not entirely sure.

At a minimum, it indicates that something originates from God in some meaningful wayâ€”that He participated in it. 
But beyond that, we're on shaky ground.

When we look at 2 Timothy 3:16, it could mean moreâ€”but we simply donâ€™t know for certain.

Thatâ€™s why I want to be careful. Iâ€™m a historian, and I try to stay within the limits of what the evidence supports. And in this case, I believe the safest conclusion is this:

Scripture is divinely inspired, in that it ultimately derives from God who approve itâ€”thus, it carries absolute authority.
.
.
.

title: Think â€œGod-breathedâ€ is a rare word? Think again.Theopneustos shows up over 2,400 times in...
description:
ğŸ“– What Does â€œGod-Breathedâ€ Really Mean?

Words change over time.
Just like â€œapologyâ€ once meant a defenseâ€”not saying â€œIâ€™m sorryâ€â€”theopneustos needs to be understood in its original context.

So how was â€œGod-breathedâ€ used in the ancient world?

ğŸ§¾ In the Sibylline Oracles, it describes rivers and â€œall thingsâ€ as theopneustosâ€”not with precision, but with the idea that God was somehow behind them.

ğŸ•Šï¸ In the Testament of Abraham, angels anoint Abrahamâ€™s body with ointments & perfumes that are God-breathedâ€”sacred, special, divinely influenced.

ğŸŒŒ Vettius Valens, a Roman astrologer, said etherâ€”an all-encompasing substanceâ€”was theopneustos. Again, God was involved in its origin.

ğŸ“œ And by the time we get to Origen in the 3rd century, he calls Scripture theopneustos 49 times. He didnâ€™t define the word, but believed Scripture came from Godâ€”even if it included surface-level contradictions. What mattered to him was its spiritual truth.

ğŸ” So why does this matter?
Because when Paul says â€œAll Scripture is God-breathedâ€ in 2 Timothy 3:16, heâ€™s pointing to divine originâ€”not dictation, not word-for-word mechanics, but a sacred source behind the message.

title: Did Josephus Mention Jesus?  (With  Dr Thomas Schmidt)
description:
Josephus is often cited as one of the strongest non Christian sources for the historical Jesus. But is that really the case? 
He mentions Jesus in two controversial passages... or does he? Scholars have debated this for decades, questioning what Josephus actually wrote, what may have been added later, and what it all means for the case of Jesus outside the Bible.
In this fascinating interview, Dr. Tom Schmidt helps us dive deep into the facts behind one of the most discussed ancient references to Jesus.

To view online or download your free PDF of Dr. Schmidt's monograph published by Oxford University Press, go to https://academic.oup.com/book/60034?login=false
About T.C.Schmidt: https://tcschmidt.com/

He believed God approved it.
He treated it as authoritative.
And He commissioned His disciples to carry that message forward.

So if the risen Jesus trusted Scriptureâ€¦

title: If we take the three-day motif literally, then there's a contradiction.
description:
In Estherâ€™s story, she commands the people to fast for three daysâ€”but then goes to the king on the third day, not after three full days.

So what gives?

This is a clue that "three days" in ancient literature was often a flexible, idiomatic expressionâ€”not a stopwatch countdown. We see this pattern in Jewish, Christian, and even Akkadian writings.

That matters when interpreting the Gospels. The timing of Jesus' resurrection isn't a contradictionâ€”it fits within the common, non-literal use of â€œthree daysâ€ at the time.

Historical context doesnâ€™t weaken Scriptureâ€”it helps us understand it more accurately.

#EarlyChurch #GospelTradition #BibleTrust  #BiblicalReliability #MikeLicona #ChristianApologetics

title: When we say "That'll take foreverâ€¦" we don't really mean forever. This is key to understanding...
description:
We use time-related exaggerations all the timeâ€”"Give me a minute" doesnâ€™t mean 60 seconds, and "Thatâ€™ll take forever" doesnâ€™t mean eternity. 
Itâ€™s just how we talk.

Ancient people did the same. When Jesus said Heâ€™d rise "on the third day" or be in the earth "three days and three nights," it wasnâ€™t meant in a sense of numerical precision. 
In Jewish, Christian, and even Akkadian literature, "three days" often just meant "a short time."

Understanding this helps us read the Gospels in their historical and literary contextâ€”not with wooden literalism, but with clarity and care.

title: What if we read the Gospels using the same techniques ancient biographers used?
description:
We often judge the Gospels by modern standardsâ€”but what if we stepped into the ancient world for a moment?

Writers like Plutarch, one of the greatest ancient biographers, regularly used paraphrasing techniques like compression and displacement when telling stories. These werenâ€™t mistakesâ€”they were standard practice.

Now imagine reading the Gospels with that same lens.
Suddenly, those â€œdifferencesâ€ begin to make sense.
They arenâ€™t contradictions. Theyâ€™re careful, purposeful storytelling in the literary style of their time.

ğŸ“œ This isnâ€™t lowering our view of Scriptureâ€”itâ€™s understanding it better.

title: Itâ€™s evident that the early church regarded the preservation of oral tradition with great care...
description:
The early church didnâ€™t treat oral tradition casuallyâ€”it was guarded with intentional leadership and doctrinal accountability.

According to Acts and Paulâ€™s undisputed letters, the apostles were based in Jerusalem, the central hub of authority in the early Christian movement. In Galatians 2 and Acts 15, even Paul submits to that leadership, showing us that the transmission of Jesusâ€™ teachings was not left to chance.

Paul also appeals to tradition in his letters. In 1 Corinthians, he uses it to settle disputes. And in 2 Thessalonians, he tells believers not to associate with those who refuse to live according to the traditions passed down to them.

These are the actions of a community committed to preserving the message of Jesus with care.

Given the structure of oral culture and apostolic leadership, we have strong reason to believe the Gospels faithfully reflect what Jesus said and did.

Jesus also taught using parables, vivid imagery, and bold language designed to stick:

title: â€œI believe we have good reason to trust the reliability of the oral traditions that have been...

title: Rethinking Inspiration & Inerrancy with Mike Licona
description:
At ApologeticCon 2025, I walked through one of the most misunderstood doctrines in Christianityâ€”what it really means to say the Bible is â€œGod-breathed.â€ 
In this session, I explored how inspiration and inerrancy have been defined historically, what Scripture itself claims, and what we actually observe in the text.

title: Plutarch never copies and pastesâ€”even when telling the same story twice.
description:

So what does that tell us about the Gospels?

In the ancient world, faithful storytelling wasnâ€™t about quoting verbatimâ€”it was about preserving meaning. When we see differences in the Gospels, they may reflect this same approach: not contradiction, but composition.

title: If someone 1000 years from now wanted to claim that 9/11 never happened, it wouldnâ€™t be hard to ...
description:
Imagine future skeptics saying that videos were forged, AI created fake evidence, or even that Hollywood masterminded the whole thing. 
They might point to the eerily similar 1945 B-25 bomber crash into the Empire State Building and claim 9/11 was just a symbolic story about economic collapse and America's global decline.
 
 Sounds ridiculous, right? Yet, this is exactly how some people treat the Gospelsâ€”assuming key events (like Jesus' flight to Egypt) were invented for theological reasons rather than being historical. 
Sure, the Gospel writers use symbolism, but that doesnâ€™t mean the events themselves didnâ€™t happen.
 
 ğŸ” Some details may carry deeper meaning, but thatâ€™s different from fabrication. Just like 9/11, the resurrection of Jesus was an unexpected, world-changing eventâ€”and the way people made sense of it afterward doesn't make it any less real.
 
 ğŸ’­ What do you think? 
Do skeptics apply different standards to biblical history? 
Letâ€™s talk in the comments! â¬‡ï¸

title: If the Resurrection Was Made Upâ€¦ They Would Have Done This Instead! ğŸ‘‡ğŸ»
description:
If the disciples were inventing a story about Jesus rising from the dead, wouldn't they have picked clear and direct Old Testament prophecies to back it up? 
Instead, what do we see in Acts? 
Peter and Paul scrambling to make sense of an unexpected realityâ€”repurposing Psalms and Hosea in ways that werenâ€™t originally about the Messiah.
 
 Why? Because they werenâ€™t expecting a dying and rising Messiah. His resurrection shocked them. They had to search the Scriptures to understand what had just happened. This isnâ€™t how people write fiction. This is how people react to something they didnâ€™t see comingâ€”and that makes their testimony even more compelling.

title: As a historian, I find something particularly interesting about how prophecy is used in the Bible...
description:
In Matthewâ€™s Gospel, we see a fascinating example of how he applies Old Testament prophecy to Jesus. 
In Hosea 11:1, the verse says:
 
 "Out of Egypt I called my son."
 
 In its original context, Hosea is referring to Israelâ€”Godâ€™s "son"â€”being rescued from Egypt during the Exodus. If you look at the surrounding verses (especially verse 10 or early verse 11), it's clear that this passage is about Israelâ€™s deliverance from bondage.
 
Biblical writers, particularly Matthew, sometimes use this approach, likely because they are thinking in terms of typology rather than strict fulfillment of prophecy. (In one of my latest posts I explained what is typology).
 
 In this case, Matthew sees Jesus as a new Israelâ€”just as Israel was called out of Egypt, so was Jesus.

title: Typology: when someone in the Bible is a foreshadowing or symbolic parallel to someone greater...
description:
Typology is when a biblical figure, event, or concept serves as a pattern or foreshadowing of something greater that comes later. Itâ€™s not about direct prophecy, but about seeing symbolic parallels in Scripture.
 
 For example, Matthew presents Jesus as a type of Moses. One way he does this is by placing Jesus' Sermon on the Mount on a mountain, even though Luke records a similar sermon as happening on a plain. Why?
 
 - In the Old Testament, Moses received Godâ€™s Law on Mount Sinai.
 - In Matthewâ€™s Gospel, Jesus delivers Godâ€™s teaching from a mountain, symbolizing that He is the new and greater Moses. 
 
 Matthew looks to highlight theological truthsâ€”showing Jesus as the fulfillment of patterns established in the Old Testament.

title: Is the Gospel of Luke a history or a biography?
description:
There is some debate about whether Lukeâ€™s Gospel should be classified as history rather than biography, especially since it is often viewed as Volume 1, with the Book of Acts as Volume 2 of a historical account.
 
 Most scholars agree that Lukeâ€™s Gospel contain's characteristics of a history. But that doesnâ€™t mean it isnâ€™t a biography. It still follows the key traits of ancient biographies:
 
 âœ… Focus on a central figure (Jesus)
 âœ… Typical biographical length
 âœ… Emphasis on deeds and sayings that reveal character
 âœ… Brief mention of ancestry (genealogy) before launching into public life
 
 A helpful comparison is Plutarchâ€™s Life of Julius Caesar, which includes historical elements but is still recognized as a biography. Similarly, the Gospel of Luke contains historical details but remains consistent with ancient biographical conventions.
.
.

title: "The historian's objective is to seek probability, not proof."
description:
In life, absolute certainty is elusive. For instance, how do we know we are as old as we think we are? Or that our birthday is really on that specific day? A birth certificate might say one thing, but could there have been a clerical error? And even if our parents confirm it, how can we be sure they didnâ€™t misunderstand the record? 
Historians work with similar uncertaintyâ€”seeking the most probable explanations based on available evidence, but never claiming absolute proof.

Want to learn more?, click here: https://rb.gy/jm0lo9

title: Scripture does not inform us how divine inspiration occurred...
description:
And different models of inspiration result in different kinds of biblical texts, some of which allow errors in the autographs.
Therefore, our speculations must attempt to have a coherent model of inspiration that takes seriously both the claims of Scripture about itself AND what we observe in Scripture. CSBI made noble efforts in this regard but fell short, because its incorrect concept of inspiration begat an incorrect concept of inerrancy. This problem can be remedied by acknowledging the confluence of Scripture and understanding inerrancy to refer to the message of Scripture. The payoff is a better understanding of Scripture and a stronger faith. 
 
 Read my paper on the subject in my website: https://www.risenjesus.com/etspaper2023

 2ï¸âƒ£ It strengthens our faith. By moving beyond rigid interpretations, we avoid painful harmonizations and affirm the inerrancy of the Bible we hold todayâ€”not just the lost autographs.
 
 A flexible view makes sense of Scriptureâ€™s claims AND the evidence we observe. Isnâ€™t that freeing? Comment "BENEFITS" if you like to read the full article.

Were these events literal history, or were they an apocalyptic literary device highlighting the significance of Jesusâ€™ death? We dive into the implications for biblical inerrancy, the use of literary genres in Scripture, and what scholars and church fathers have said about this passage. Join us for an engaging discussion on this fascinating topic!

title: Realizing that the Gospel authors felt free to report with some elasticity makes some uncom....
description:
But a principle I have come to live by is this: I must accept the Gospels as God has given them to us rather than forcing them into a mold of how I think He should have. If I fail to do this, I may believe I have a high view of Scripture when, in reality, I merely have a high view of MY view of Scripture. That would constitute misguided piety.

title: The more I study the Gospels within their cultural context, the literary conventions of that day,
description:
Years ago, I imagined the authors of the Gospels had simply reported what they had seen and heard in manners similar to those we use today. Now I see the Gospel authors doing much more. They wrote accurate accounts of Jesus and, to different degrees, wrote with literary artistry that sometimes sacrificed precision in order to communicate points more clearly and to bring out the even deeper meanings behind them. Matthewâ€™s genealogy is another clear example where this occurs.
 
 #Christianity #Apologetics #ChristianApologetics #Gospels #Scripture
____________________

title: Why I decided to include chapters on inspiration and inerrancy in my latest book.
description:
In this deep dive, we unpack what it truly means when the Bible is described as "God-breathed" (2 Timothy 3:16). Does divine inspiration guarantee inerrancy in the original texts? How have scholars throughout history interpreted "inspiration"? And what does it mean for us if there are errors in the Bible we have today? Explore ancient usages of "God-breathed," the context of New Testament scriptures, and the nuanced relationship between inspiration and the preservation of truth.

title: Am I De-Historicizing" Matthewâ€™s Raised Saints? Letâ€™s Clear the Air ğŸ‘‡ğŸ»
description:
Some of my critics claimed I was de-historicizing Matthew's account of the raised saints. But here's the thing: if Matthew never intended for this to be understood as a historical event, then I'm not de-historicizingâ€”I'm simply interpreting it as it was meant to be.
 
Now, if Matthew did intend it as history, and I still interpreted it otherwise, then yes, I'd be disagreeing with him. But thatâ€™s not the case here. My goal has always been to stay true to the textâ€™s intentâ€”even if I could be wrong in my approach.

title: I once pointed out that Jehovahâ€™s Witnesses believe the Bible is without errorâ€”but ...
description:
Itâ€™s not about rejecting or accepting inerrancy; itâ€™s about hermeneutics. 
 
 That statement caused a stirâ€”one individual was shocked Iâ€™d even suggest such a thing! But this reaction highlights a key misunderstanding: confusing the inerrancy of the text with the inerrancy of our interpretations.
 
 As my friend Michael Bird puts it so well:
 "They preach the inerrancy of the Bible but practice the inerrancy of their interpretations."
 
 Letâ€™s be careful not to elevate our understanding to the same level as Scripture itself. Our interpretations may be flawed, but the Word remains true. ğŸ“–
 
 What do you think? How do we guard against conflating the two? Letâ€™s discuss! ğŸ‘‡

title: The wooden view that requires harmonization can be dangerous to one's faith.
description:

When this rigid view begins to crack, it can lead to severe doubts and a rapid unraveling of belief. A healthier, more nuanced understanding of inspiration is crucial for a faith that endures.

title: Since 1799 the most common criticism of Christianity has been the perceived discrepancies in the...
description:
Consider these powerful thoughts from Gary Habermas during our last Q&A session: Since 1799, with Frederick Schleiermacher and his liberal successors to the present day, the most common criticism of Christianity has been the perceived discrepancies in the Gospels. Interestingly, many people recognize these discrepancies yet still believe in Jesus's resurrection.

The key issue lies in how we define the gospel according to the New Testament, which centers on Jesus' deity, death, and resurrection. While there may be minor inconsistencies, they do not undermine the core events of the Gospel. This explains how individuals can acknowledge these issues and still affirm the truth of the resurrection.

If Christ is the Son of God who died on the cross and rose from the dead, then Christianity is true. Reflect on that: the deity, death, and resurrection of Christ confirm the truth of Christianityâ€”end of story. I stand firm on that conviction.

#Christianity #GaryHabermas #Resurrection #GospelTruth #Deity #Death #Resurrection #Faith #BiblicalTruth #Apologetics #ChristianFaith #TruthInChrist #DiscrepanciesInGospels #QandA

title: Christ spoke through Paul. Yet minor errors in speech didnâ€™t undermine his message.
description:
In 2 Corinthians, Paul addresses members of the Corinthian church who were challenging his authority. He says, "You want proof that Christ is speaking through me?" Now, if any verse ever conveyed the sense of being â€œGod-breathedâ€ or divinely inspired, itâ€™s this oneâ€”Paul explicitly stating that Christ is speaking through him.

Paul is referring to moments when he preached the gospel and shared Christ's teachingsâ€”Christ was speaking through him. But does that mean Paul never made a small error, like misattributing a prophecy to the wrong prophet, perhaps saying Jeremiah when it was Isaiah? In 30-plus years of preaching, are we to believe that never happened? Or that he never confused the location of a miracle Jesus performed? Itâ€™s almost certain these kinds of minor errors occurredâ€”not just with Paul, but with other apostles too. Think about the thousands of times the apostles preached over the decades before the last one passed away. Minor mistakes were inevitable.

So, if the apostles could make small errors when Christ was speaking through them while they preached, why not when they were writing? After all, both situations would have been under the inspiration of the Holy Spirit. If Christ was speaking through them in their preaching, it seems plausible that minor details might be imperfect in their writings as well. So, there are better terms for describing Scripture than how "inerrancy" as it is traditionally understood.
____________________

title: Ever heard of Literary Spotlighting? ğŸŒŸ
description:
Imagine you're at a theater performance. The stage is filled with actors, but suddenly, the lights dim, and a spotlight shines on one performer delivering a powerful monologue. You know the others are present, but your attention is drawn solely to that one person. Thatâ€™s exactly what literary spotlighting is!
 
 Authors often use this technique to focus on a key figure while acknowledging the presence of others in the background. We see this in the Gospels too! For instance, in the resurrection narratives, John mentions only Mary Magdalene visiting the tomb. But when she says, â€œwe donâ€™t know where theyâ€™ve laid him,â€ sheâ€™s referring to the other women who were with her! ğŸ¤”
 
 This technique helps convey essential messages while still recognizing the broader context. So next time you read, pay attention to those literary spotlights illuminating key moments in the text! ğŸ’¡
 
 #LiterarySpotlighting #AncientLiterature #Plutarch #GospelNarratives #BibleStudy #Resurrection #MaryMagdalene #TheaterOfWords #BiblicalLiterature #ChristianityExplained #InsightfulReading #ScriptureStudy____________________

title: Jesus actually survived the crucifixion?
description:
There is no compelling reason to deny that Jesus died by crucifixion. The evidence supporting this fact from the first century is robust, and without any credible evidence to the contrary, historians must conclude that Jesus was indeed crucified and that this process led to his death. Of course, if youâ€™re a skeptic and wish to propose an alternative view, youâ€™re free to do so. However, it's important to recognize that trained historians and thoughtful individuals are unlikely to endorse such claims without substantial evidence.

title: My Bookâ€™s Most Controversial Issue: What Critics Are Saying w/ @FreethinkingMinistries
description:
In this video, I share the major concerns my critics, who disagree with my approach to the discrepancies among the Gospels, have. From their point of view, my theory implies these discrepancies result from deliberate redactions by the Gospel authors. In other words, they argue that the Gospel writers intentionally described events in ways that contradict what they believed happened. Let's dive into this perspective and why I found it bewildering!
 
 Secure your copy of my book here: https://www.amazon.com/Jesus-Contradicted-Gospels-Story-Differently/dp/0310159598

title: Is Intelligent Design Just Another 'God of the Gaps' Theory?
description:
In this video, we tackle the common accusation of a "God of the gaps" argumentâ€”where believers are said to invoke God to explain the unknown. We dive into the key distinctions between the traditional "God of the gaps" approach and Intelligent Design, which offers a robust, evidence-based framework. Join us as we clarify the misconceptions and discuss how intelligent design differs from simply using God to fill in the gaps.

title: Beyond Wooden Notions: Rethinking Reliability with Flexibility!
description:
Join us as we delve into the intriguing question of purposeful changes in the Gospels. Many wonder: Do intentional alterations render the text untrustworthy? As Christians, relying on the Gospels for evidence of our faith, understanding these dynamics is crucial. This discussion explores how historical accuracy intersects with ancient storytelling techniques, shedding light on how we perceive the reliability of the Gospel narratives. What are your thoughts on this issue? Let's explore together!

title: Mike Licona Responds to Bill Roach Part 2
description:
A critic of Dr. Mike Licona (Dr. Bill Roach) has challenged Licona on his claims regarding JI Packer, as well as his understanding of the Chicago Statement, inerrancy, and inspiration. Here, Licona reacts to some of what Roach has said. This is part two of two videos reacting to Roach. The first is available at: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=x_A2waU3fFc

Bill Roach's video to which Licona is responding may be viewed at Bill Roachâ€™s video: https://youtu.be/Fjwo12AhVOE

At 1:26:19, I respond to Roach's claim that I turned his book "Defending Inerrancy" into an "anti-Mike" book. As part of my response, I claimed that he and his co-author Norman Geisler had to self-publish it because no publisher was interested in it. Whereas it is true that a major publisher told me that Dr. Geisler had approached it with a book proposal, which they had declined, Dr. Roach corrected me that "Defending Inerrancy" was not that book and that he and Dr. Geisler had proposed that book to Baker and they accepted it immediately. As a result, I want to apologize for my inaccurate claim and set the record straight. 
____________________

description:
In this in-depth conversation with @michaelsbeverly, I delve into the topic of my new book, ""Jesus, Contradicted."" We explore the differences in the Gospels and how to view them. This engaging dialogue between a believer and a skeptic offers fresh perspectives and thought-provoking insights. Don't miss this fascinating exchange!
 
Check out my new book: https://www.amazon.com/Jesus-Contradicted-Gospels-Story-Differently/dp/0310159598
____________________

title: A Closer Look on The Resurrection of Jesus.
description:
Join Dr. Michael Licona as he delves into the historical evidence surrounding the resurrection of Jesus: Facts or fiction? Through an engaging discussion, Dr. Licona explains the methodology of historical research and the challenges faced by historians in interpreting the past, he presents the historical bedrock and the importance of corroborating data to establish a solid case for the resurrection, exploring the evidence and addressing objections to the resurrection hypothesis. Don't miss this crucial information! This event took place at Ohio State University on April 11, 2024.
____________________

description:

Join us as we navigate these significant themes with thoughtfulness and insight.

Evans' article can be read at https://aeon.co/essays/why-the-son-of-god-story-is-built-on-mythology-not-history

title: New Testament Scholar discusses the New Living Translation and DMin program at HCU
description:
On this occasion, Mike Licona interviews leading New Testament scholar Lynn Cohick. Lynn Cohick has served as Professor Dean and Provost at several academic institutions, including Wheaton College, Denver Seminary, and Northern Seminary, and is currently a distinguished professor of New Testament at Houston Christian University and director of Houston Theological Seminary.
 In this interview, Mike and Lynn discuss the New Living Translation, Lynn's new commentary on Ephesians, her joining the HCU faculty, and the Master of Divinity and Doctor of Ministry degrees she directs.
 
 Learn more about Lynn Cohick: https://www.lynncohick.com
 
 Learn more about the MDiv & DMin programs at HCU/HTS: https://hc.edu/houston-theological-seminary/dmin/

title: Frank Turek Interviews Mike Licona on Jesus' Resurrection | @CrossExamined
description:
Do Christians have good historical reasons to put our faith in the resurrection of Jesus? Can we really know what happened 2,000 years ago? No one doubts the works of Alexander the Great, and Julius Caesar, or the history written about them, so what makes the historicity of Jesus so special? And what do non-Christian scholars say about the evidence for the resurrection of Jesus?

Don't miss this special episode of 'I Don't Have Enough Faith to Be an Atheist,' where Frank Turek and I discuss several essential topics about Jesus and the resurrection.

title: The Minimal Facts Approach: Braxton Hunter, Gary Habermas, and Mike Licona Discuss
description:
The Minimal Facts Approach takes only those relevant facts that are (a) strongly supported by the data and (b) are granted by a very large and heterogenous consensus of scholars. In this interview, Braxton Hunter, Gary Habermas, and Mike Licona discuss what the minimal facts approach is, its value, and answer some recent criticisms of it. This interview originally appeared on Trinity Radio's channel: https://youtu.be/KVCiiuvnQlM. Used with permission.

title: Replying to My Friend Bart Ehrman
description: On June 16, 2022, Bart Ehrman posted on his blog, "Are Christian apologists just being dishonest?" The matter is discussed because, apparently, a number of skeptics think some of the answers given by Christian Apologists are so out of touch that those giving them could not possibly believe what they're saying. Bart likewise finds some answers provided by Christian Apologists difficult to swallow and specifically mentions how Mike Licona answers the difference in how Matthew and Luke report Jesus' instructing his disciples before sending them out. Did he tell them to take a staff or not take one? Bart does not think at least some Christian apologists, perhaps even most of them are intentionally being dishonest. He just thinks they are terribly misguided. Mike Licona responds in this video.

title: Historical evidence that Jesus actually predicted His death | Highlight
description:
Christians and Muslims both regard Jesus as a prophet, and they also agree the prophecies of a true prophet are always fulfilled. The canonical gospels, Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John, portray Jesus prophesying his imminent death on several occasions. Although historians cannot prove that Jesus uttered each and every one of those predictions, they can establish with a high degree of historical certainty that Jesus prophesied His imminent death.

title: The students of the disciples talk about the resurrection | Highlight
description:

title: Victory in Tragedy: What Charlotte Thomason learned in her Near Death Experience
description:
Charlotte Thomason was repeatedly raped by her father, became pregnant and both she and her baby died in childbirth. Charlotte had a near-death experience (NDE) in which she met Jesus - and her baby. She was told she could not stay because there was work for her to do. What has happened with Charlotte since that experience? Charlotte explains and tells those who are victims of abuse that there is hope! This is a 31-minute video in which Mike Licona interviews Charlotte.

title: What happens when we die: Soul Sleep or Conscious in Heaven?
description:
Letters written by the apostle Paul represent perhaps the earliest Christian literature. Because Paul had close ties to the Jerusalem apostles who had walked with Jesus and had certified that Paul's gospel teaching was aligned with their own (Gal. 2:1-10), Paul's statements about what happens to followers of Jesus after their death have direct implications on how he viewed the resurrection of Jesus. In this 7 minute video, Dr. Mike Licona discusses these things.

title: Man or Myth? Did Jesus Exist?
description:
Original Video https://www.youtube.com/c/MikeWinger 
Mike Licona addresses the matter of whether Jesus truly existed. Today, it is common to find skeptics on the Internet, called "mythicists," claiming Jesus was a myth who never existed. But what do data from antiquity suggest? Can a good historical case be made for the existence of Jesus in the first century? Or is the mere belief that he existed something that must be taken on faith only? Or are there good reasons to think Jesus was no more than a myth? Mike Licona answers in this interview.

title: Dale Allison & Mike Licona Discuss the Resurrection of Jesus Part 1
description:
In this 4-Part series, Dale Allison and Mike Licona discuss Professor Allison's life and his new book "The Resurrection of Jesus: Apologetics, Polemics, History," which is due to be available March 11, 2021. Dale Allison is the Richard J. Dearborn Professor of New Testament Studies at Princeton Theological Seminary. This video is Part 1 and deals exclusively with the personal life and journey of Dale Allison. Those only interested in learning his thoughts on the resurrection of Jesus should go directly to Part 2. 

What does one of today's most highly respected New Testament scholars think about the resurrection of Jesus? Is it fiction? Did the disciples hallucinate? Is "resurrection" a metaphor for something else the earliest Christians were attempting to communicate? Or did Jesus actually return from the dead and appear to others? title: Understanding the Deuterocanonical Books
description:
What are the "Deuterocanonical" books? Mike Licona interviews the foremost expert on the topic of canon formation, Lee Martin McDonald. In this video, they discuss the Apocrypha, Deuterocanonical literature, English Protestant Bibles, Eastern Orthodoxy, and the Catholic Church. Ultimately, they review how various Christian traditions regard non-canonical books. Are they useful? Are they inspired? Are they heretical?

title: Was Peter Mark's Source for the Gospel of Mark?
description:
Church tradition states that the Gospel of Mark is based on what Mark remembered Peter reporting. However, many scholars doubt this claim. What do the data suggest and what do most of today's scholars think about this matter? Join Mike Licona and Josh Pelletier as they discuss the possibility of Petrine recollections in Mark's Gospel.

Josh Pelletier is a former student of Mike's at Houston Baptist University. Mike served as Josh's supervisor for his thesis, which included the matters of when Mark's Gospel was composed, the authorship of Mark, and whether there is a connection between Mark's Gospel and the apostle Peter. The first two topics are covered in Parts 1 and 2 of this 3 Part series.

Mike Licona is associate professor of theology at Houston Baptist University. HBU offers a fully accredited Master of Arts degree in apologetics that may be completed entirely online or on the HBU campus in Houston. For more information, visit https://bit.ly/2Wlej6Z.

title: Who wrote the Gospel of Mark?
description:

What do the data suggest? What are the pro and con arguments? And what do the majority of critical scholars think? Josh Pelletier has done the research and answers these questions.

title: Lydia McGrew Answered! Conclusion
description:
The final video in a series of 8. Mike Licona reviews Lydia McGrew's criticisms in her book "The Mirror or the Mask." In this video, Mike summarizes what he perceives are the problems with McGrew's approach. He then suggests what lay at the root of the disagreement and some ways forward.

Lydia McGrew has been criticizing New Testament scholars in general and, especially Mike Licona's book "Why Are There Differences in the Gospels? What We Can Learn From Ancient Biography" (New York: OUP, 2017). Because Mike usually has no interest in "in-house theological debates," he has refused to respond for the past few years. However, the division this in-house debate is causing in the Body of Christ and the many continuous requests he has received to reply to McGrew has led to his decision to offer this response. 

A semi-polished transcript of all videos in this series is available at https://www.risenjesus.com/lydia-mcgrew-answered.

title: Lydia McGrew Answered! On Paraphrase
description:
Part 3 in a series of 8. Mike Licona gives attention to Lydia McGrew's contentions that historians in antiquity would not have employed the exercises (progymnasmata) taught in the compositional textbooks by Theon, Quintilian, and others. McGrew's book "The Mirror or the Mask" is largely a critique of Mike Licona's book "Why Are There Differences in the Gospels? What We Can Learn From Ancient Biography" (New York: OUP, 2017). But it is also a broad scale critique of the widespread opinions of classicists and New Testament scholars that ancient historians used compositional devices. 

Because Mike usually has no interest in "in-house theological debates," he has refused to respond for the past few years. However, the division in the Body of Christ this in-house debate is causing and the many continuous requests he has received to reply to McGrew has led to his decision to offer this response.

A semi-polished transcript of all videos in this series is available at https://www.risenjesus.com/lydia-mcgrew-answered.

Mike Licona is associate professor of theology at Houston Baptist University. HBU offers a fully accredited Master of Arts degree in apologetics that may be completed entirely online or on the HBU campus in Houston. For more information, visit https://bit.ly/2Wlej6Z.

title: Were People Raised When Jesus Died?
description:
Matthew 27:51-53 report a number of portents that occurred when Jesus died: the temple curtain tore from top to bottom, there was an earthquake, the rocks split, the tombs were opened, many saints were raised from the dead. After Jesus's resurrection, these saints came out of the tombs, went into the Holy City and appeared to many. Matthew is the only Gospel to report the earthquake, the rocks splitting, the tombs opening, and saints rising the dead. If we had actually been present in Jerusalem at the moment of Jesus's death, would we have seen multiple corpses coming back to life? Dr. Licona shares what he thinks.

The matter of Matthew's raised saints was discussed in detail in a virtual roundtable, consisting of Mike Licona, Craig Blomberg, Paul Copan, Michael Kruger, Chuck Quarles, and Danny Akin. This discussion in its entirety may be read at https://bit.ly/3f5amdV

title: Was Jesus's Resurrection Only a Metaphor?
description:
Some scholars, such as John Dominic Crossan have asserted that when the early Christians said "Christ is Risen," they did not intend to communicate Jesus had been raised bodily from the dead. Instead they used "resurrection" as a metaphor for Jesus's influence, which could still be felt. But is this really what the early Christians were claiming? In this short video, Dr. Licona gives one reason why Dr. Crossan and others cannot be correct.

This video can be viewed with subtitles in Spanish at https://youtu.be/ufKk697z6_o

title: Did The Disciples Hallucinate Jesus?
description:
Perhaps today's most common alternative explanation to Jesus's resurrection is the apostles and Paul experienced hallucinations of the risen Jesus. After all, Jesus's disciples were grieving over his sudden and brutal death, perhaps also leading to sleep deprivation. In this short video, Dr. Licona offers several reasons why the hallucination hypothesis falls far short of adequately explaining the appearances of Jesus.

title: The Apostle Paul
description:
Saul of Tarsus persecuted the Christian Church shortly after Jesus's death, seeking to destroy it. Then he had an experience he was convinced was the risen Jesus appearing to him. He changed from persecuting the Church to being persecuted. Paul's letters comprise approximately one third of the entire New Testament.

title: What Others Are Saying About Mike Licona's Book
description:
Have you noticed differences in how the Gospels report the same events? Are there contradictions in the Gospels? In his ground-breaking research, Mike Licona built on the work of classicists who identified various compositional devices used by the ancients when writing biographies. Reading the Gospels with these devices in mind sheds much light on why Gospel differences appear. In this video, two professors at Oklahoma Baptist University express appreciation for Licona's work and how it has opened their eyes to a new way for them to understand why there are differences in the Gospels.

Now Alex uses several of the arguments Licona used in that debate when speaking with atheists.

title: Why Are Some Worship Leaders Leaving Christianity?
description:
In the summer of 2019, worship leader Marty Sampson of Hillsongs announced that he was experiencing serious doubts over whether Christianity is true. That same summer, Joshua Harris, pastor and author of "I Kissed Dating Goodbye" renounced his Christian faith, announced that he and his wife were separating and that he now supports same-sex marriage. In 2020, Christian music artist Jon Steingard renounced his Christian faith. In this video, Mike & Debbie Licona discuss the matter of doubting one's Christian faith. What causes doubt? Is it wrong to doubt? Does God get mad at us when we doubt? What should I do when I doubt? How should I respond to another Christian who is doubting?

Mike Licona is associate professor of theology at Houston Baptist University. HBU offers a fully accredited Master of Arts degree in apologetics that may be completed entirely online or on the HBU campus in Houston. For more information, visit https://bit.ly/2Wlej6Z.

title: Near Death Experience: An Unexpected Conversation With Jesus
description:
Near Death Experience (NDE). What happens when we die? Is there life after death? Is there a heaven? Every year I teach a course on the Gospels at Houston Baptist University for the Master of Arts Degree in Christian Apologetics. Doing the course, I ask my students if any of them have ever experienced a miracle. Usually, there are some who say they have and some have not. Of those who claim to have experienced a miracle, 1 or 2 of them have a testimony describing an experience that is quite extraordinary. One of those students in my 2018 course offering is Charlotte Thomason.

Note: Yes, I know the music is too loud. I can't change that now. So, there's no need to mention it in the comments.

At age 11, Charlotte died after giving birth. In this video she describes what happened in moments before she revived.  Her conversation with Jesus is not what you expect!

Charlotte Thomason holds a Master of Science in Social Work from the University of Texas at Austin and will graduate in May 2019 with a Master of Arts in Cultural Apologetics from Houston Baptist University. Prior to her retirement in 2015, Charlotte worked in Foster Care and Adoption for over 30 years, both with the State and in the private sector.

Charlotte's story is a powerful testimony of redemption and healing after she endured abuse perpetrated by multiple people from age 5-18. Charlotte reflects, "I recall how I did plead. I did pray. While the prayers did not stop the abuse at the hands of my father, uncle, or others, I never felt that heaven watched with indifference. My belief in Christ sustained me."

For more about Charlotte's story go to: charlottethomason.com

description: Mike & Debbie Licona wish you a Merry Christmas and a Happy New Year!

title: Did Jesus's Prophecy to Return Fail?
description: Jesus told His disciples he would return before some of them died. But all of them have died and Jesus has yet to return. Did His prophecy fail or is something else going on? In this video, Dr. Licona spells out three options.

title: Was JESUS' RESURRECTION a METAPHOR?
description: Some scholars have claimed that, by Jesus's resurrection, the earliest Christians meant only that God had exalted Jesus in heaven and did not have in mind that Jesus's corpse had returned to life. In this short video, Dr. Licona shows why such claims are false.

title: Was JESUS' TOMB EMPTY?
description: Mike Licona provides 3 primary evidences that Jesus's tomb was empty: (1) The Jerusalem Factor; (2) the empty tomb is indirectly attested to by Jesus's enemies; (3) the primary witnesses of the empty tomb are women, which is an unlikely invention given their status in the first century Jewish and Greco-Roman cultures.

title: Did the disciples HALLUCINATE the RISEN JESUS?
description: In this video, Mike Licona explores the possibility that Jesus's disciples experienced hallucinations and mistook them for being the risen Jesus appearing to them.

title: Sermon on the Mount
description: While in Israel in October 2017, Mike Licona was asked to recite Jesus's Sermon on the Mount at a location close to where Jesus is thought to have given it nearly 2,000 years ago.

title: Resurrection Parallels 5 of 5
description: In this 5 Part Series, Mike Licona explains why scholars have rejected the claim that the early Christians borrowed the idea of resurrection from pagan myths. In Part 5, Licona observes that the abundance of romantic fiction does not cast doubt on authentic romance. Instead, it reveals an insatiable appetite in humans for romance. In a similar way, a number of accounts of people returning from the dead does not cast doubt on a well-evidenced account, such as Jesus' resurrection. Instead, it reveal a deep longing in people for immortality and the hope of God making things right.

title: Resurrection Parallels 4 of 5
description: In this 5 Part Series, Mike Licona explains why scholars have rejected the claim that the early Christians borrowed the idea of resurrection from pagan myths. In Part 4, Licona explains how figures having details about them similar to those of Jesus are not impressive when observed individually. So, one must appeal to a number of figures to form a composite figure that looks like Jesus. And this is not persuasive.

title: Resurrection Parallels 3 of 5
description: In this 5 Part Series, Mike Licona explains why scholars have rejected the claim that the early Christians borrowed the idea of resurrection from pagan myths. In Part 3, Licona explains that parallels can be found for just about anything, given the abundance of events in human history. Yet, there is no causal connection between most of them.

title: Resurrection Parallels 2 of 5
description: In this 5 Part Series, Mike Licona explains why scholars have rejected the claim that the early Christians borrowed the idea of resurrection from pagan myths. In Part 2, Licona contends that it's implausible that the Christians would have borrowed from pagan myths given their sensitivity to the Jewish Law and traditions.

title: Resurrection Parallels 1 of 5
description: In this 5 Part Series, Mike Licona explains why scholars have rejected the claim that the early Christians borrowed the idea of resurrection from pagan myths. In Part 1, Licona explains that the resurrection of dying and rising gods in the Ancient Near Eastern world were always linked to the agricultural cycles and featured figures who had lived in the distant past. However, the resurrection of Jesus was not linked to the agricultural cycles and featured a person who had lived within the lifetime of the authors of the New Testament literature.

title: Come visit our web site
description: Come visit Mike Licona's web site: https://www.risenjesus.com. On it you will find videos of Mike's debates and lectures and articles he has written. Want to have Mike speak to your group? Check out the "Speaking" section for information.

title: Is a Miracle the Least Probable Explanation?
description: In this short clip, Dr. Mike Licona respond to Matt Dillahunty's claim that miracles are always the least probably explanation.

title: Evidence for Jesus Resurrection in 30 seconds
description: Here's the best historical evidence for Jesus' resurrection in a nutshell (31 seconds). For a comprehensive case, see Mike Licona's book "The Resurrection of Jesus: A New Historiographical Approach" and/or view his debates on the topic at www.risenjesus.com

title: Did Jesus claim to be God?
description: Most scholars agree that the Gospel of John portrays Jesus claiming to be God's uniquely divine Son and that the apostle Paul made similar claims. However, there is no agreement among scholars that Jesus actually claimed to be divine. In this lecture, Mike Licona provides a simple yet powerful historical case that Jesus claimed to be divine.

title: The day I met President Ronald Reagan
description: In 1988, Mike & Debbie Licona were given a private tour of the White House by a friend who was a Secret Service agent. President Reagan was out of town that day. So, Mike & Debbie had next to no chance they would see him. However, a tragic event led the President to return. And Mike & Debbie were there.

title: Islamic Catch 22: Muslim Apologists Answer
description:
Jesus predicted his imminent death and resurrection. The Quran asserts that Jesus did not die but God only made it appear that he had (4:157-58). If Jesus did not die, he was a false prophet and the Quran is mistaken when it claims he's a true prophet. If Jesus died as he predicted, the Quran is mistaken when it asserts he did not. Either way, it appears the Quran is mistaken pertaining to Jesus. This is called the Islamic Catch-22. 

Muslim apologists must, therefore, deny that Jesus predicted his death. How do they do this, given the strong historical evidence that Jesus predicted his death? In this video, Dr. Licona addresses some of those objections.

title: CruciFICTION
description:
Muslim apologist Ahmed Deedat famously referred to the story that Jesus died by crucifixion as cruciFICTION. This was because the Quran denies that Jesus died. Was Jesus crucified? Did he die on a cross? In this video, Dr. Licona examines whether the Quran is a reliable source pertaining to the fate of Jesus. Using 3 texts and identifying a pattern throughout the Gospels, he contends that Jesus actually predicted his imminent death. This creates a dilemma for Islam. The Quran states that Jesus did not die. So, if the Quran is correct here, then Jesus is a false prophet because he predicted his imminent death and it did not come true. But the Quran would then be mistaken when referring to Jesus as a prophet. On the other hand, if Jesus died as he had predicted, the Quran is mistaken when it says he did not. Either way, the Quran is mistaken pertaining to Jesus' fate. Dr. Licona refers to this as the "Islamic Catch-22."

title: Gospel Differences & Compositional Textbooks
description:
Training in rhetoric was part of the educational process for aspiring authors in antiquity. That process included work using compositional textbooks, also referred to as rhetorical handbooks. Exercises in these trained the student to alter texts in the interest of paraphrasing. Not surprisingly, when reading ancient texts, including the Gospels, we observe their authors altering their source texts as trained. This practice resulted in differences in the way a story was reported. The differences are minor but of interest.

title: Why are there differences in the Gospels?
description: Ancient biography differs in some ways from its modern cousin. But how? In this video, Mike Licona examines the ancient biographer Plutarch and discerns a number of compositional devices he employed that resulted in differences between his own accounts. Mike then examines the Gospels and concludes that their authors employed similar devices that resulted in a number of the differences observed between them.

title: Slideshow Presentation of Mike Licona's Risen Jesus Ministry
The TOP 3 OBJECTIONS TO THE GOSPELS: ANSWERED!
description:
This video addresses 3 major objections to the historical reliability of the Gospels: (1) The actual authors of the Gospels are unknown, (2) The authors of the Gospels were biased and had an agenda, (3) The Gospels contradict one another. Dr. Mike Licona addresses these objections in this lecture.
